facts.text: Appellant (accused No. 1) along with accused Nos. 2, 3, 5 and 6 charged with transferring by sale 10 High Denomination Bank Notes of Rs. 1,000 each to Velji Lakhamshi Joshi for Rs. 1,800 at Rs. 180 per note on July 11, 1953, contravening s. 4 of High Denomination Bank Notes (Demonetisation) Ordinance, 1946 (Ordinance No. III of 1946), punishable under s. 7 r/w s. 109 IPC.
Appellant convicted by Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay in Case No. 9/P of 1954 on January 3, 1955; sentenced to fine of Rs. 8,000 and in default 6 months rigorous imprisonment.

Appellant filed Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1955 to Bombay High Court; State filed Criminal Revision Application No. 435 of 1955 for enhancement of sentence; High Court confirmed conviction and sentence on April 14, 1955.
High Denomination Bank Notes (Demonetisation) Ordinance, 1946 promulgated by Governor-General on January 12, 1946.
India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 passed on June 27, 1940; emergency period from June 27, 1940 to April 1, 1946 per His Majesty's Order in Council published April 1, 1946.
Appellant applied for certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) to High Court, dismissed; obtained special leave under Art. 136 from Supreme Court.
Ordinance listed in Second Schedule of Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950 with adaptations.
Jammu and Kashmir Extension of Laws Act, 1956 (LXII of 1956) passed September 25, 1956, extending Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 to J&K and adding s. 26A.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Denomination Bank Notes (Demonetisation) Ordinance, 1946 (Ordinance No. III of 1946) was in operation on July 11, 1953, when the offence under s. 7 read with s. 4 thereof was committed by the appellant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ordinance lapsed ipso facto on April 1, 1946 when emergency declared ended, as promulgated under emergency powers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 72 Ninth Sch. Government of India Act, 1935; India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940

petitioner_arguments.text: Alternatively, s. 72 restored to original terms from April 1, 1946, limiting Ordinance to no more than six months from promulgation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 72 Ninth Sch. Government of India Act, 1935 as originally stood

respondent_arguments.text: Omission of 'for the space of no more than six months from its promulgation' from s. 72 by India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940 made Ordinances promulgated during emergency period perpetual until repealed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 1(3) India and Burma Emergency Provisions Act, 1940; equated to Acts of Indian Legislature

court_reasoning.text: Emergency was condition for exercise of power under s. 72 but not for duration of Ordinance; omission of six-month limit during emergency period made such Ordinances perpetual like Acts of Legislature until repealed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ordinances promulgated June 27, 1940 to April 1, 1946 equated with perpetual Acts.

court_reasoning.text: No retrospective restoration of original s. 72 terms post-April 1, 1946 for Ordinances already promulgated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duration determined by s. 72 as modified during promulgation period.

court_reasoning.text: Ordinance continued per Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950 and later laws like Jammu and Kashmir Extension of Laws Act, 1956.

holdings.text: High Denomination Bank Notes (Demonetisation) Ordinance, 1946 was in operation on July 11, 1953.

precedents_cited.case_name: King Emperor v. Benoari Lall Sharma and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Ordinances under s.72 temporary even without six-month limit, for emergency.
Ordinance power limited by emergency existence and duration.

precedents_cited.case_name: J. K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co., Rampur Ltd. and others v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Ordinances under modified s.72 perpetual until repealed, emergency for power not duration.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that the High Denomination Bank Notes (Demonetisation) Ordinance, 1946 was in operation on July 11, 1953, confirming the conviction and sentence of fine Rs. 8,000 and in default six months rigorous imprisonment imposed by trial court and affirmed by High Court.

key_quotes.text: "The effect of the deletion of these words from s. 72 ... had the necessary effect of equating the Ordinances which were promulgated between June 27, 1940, and April 1, 1946, with Acts passed by the Indian Legislature without any limitation of time as regards their duration."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on perpetual nature of Ordinance.

key_quotes.text: "Ordinances thus promulgated were perpetual in duration and continued in force until they were repealed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines Ordinance's validity on offence date.

key_quotes.text: "The emergency under which the Governor-General was invested with the power ... did not impose any limitation on the duration of the Ordinances thus promulgated."
key_quotes.speaker: court
